feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
16/04 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fifty-first edition:

Laura:
  • t – Tweet from the command line, because YES REALLY.
  • typing.io – A Typing trainer for programmers
  • Hack Spots – Fork'n'Go! Make a map of your favorite hackspots
Alex:
  • The good parts – Ruby: the good parts by amberbit
  • Active Admin – 8 Useful ActiveAdmin Customizations
  • DRY Sass – Removing Sass Duplication Using Sass Maps
Ben:
  • Rails – Rails 4.1 just got released
  • UTF-8 – fixing Rails' ArgumentError: invalid byte sequence in UTF-8 forever
  • Refactoring – Refactoring Techniques

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
09/04 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fiftieth edition:

Laura:
  • Contributing to Open Source – A small GitHub guide
  • Must-have Git aliases – Some advanced examples
  • Offline First – An article on designing offline-first web apps
Alex:
  • Rails 4 overview – Visual overview of Ruby on Rails 4
  • Workflow gem – A finite state machine library.
  • Sidekiq 3.0! – Sidekiq 3.0 is out.
Ben:
  • HyperLogLog Craig Kerstiens: Scalable Uniques in Postgres
  • Docker – Getting Started with Docker
  • Analytics – Analytics for hackers: How to think about event data

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
02/04 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • Looking for pull requests – Contributing to projects, one pull request at a time
  • Don’t fear the internet – Basic HTML&CSS for non-web designers
  • Vim-CSS-Color – Highlight colors in CSS files
Alex:
  • How to build a rails engine – Brandon Hilkert’s final post leading up the the launch of the Build a Ruby Gem Ebook.
  • WTF, HTML and CSS? – Reasons HTML and CSS might make you say what the fuck.
  • tco gem – Terminal colours made simple
Ben:
  • Thread safety with Ruby – thread safety with ruby, about data mutability and difficult synchronization.
  • Pass – A Unix password manager with a new CLI interface
  • Git Review – A Review of the Git source code

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
26/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • term2048 – play 2048 in your terminal.
  • CSS Diner – practice your css selectors
  • Hacking Passion – Katrina Owen’s Lone Star Ruby 2013 Keynote
Alex:
  • What I did the last days. – All the news I have: I am skiing :)
Ben:
  • Memory inside Linux containers – Or why donâ€™t free and top work in a Linux container?
  • Microservice Architecture
  • Solving Hard Things Early Facebook VP of Engineering on Solving Hard Things Early

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
19/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • So you think you know Vim? – Is it a quiz? Is it a game?
  • Gutter Color – A Sublime Text 3 Package
  • Gittip – Sustainable Crowdfunding for your favorite people
Alex:
  • Feature Flipper for Rails – Flip lets you declare and manage feature flags
  • Testing at Airbnb – “[…]The bar to writing tests should be, ‘so low you can trip over it.’[…]”
  • Github Pull Request Triage tool – Its goal is to try to get an overview of what needs to happen next to open pull requests.
